Jane Flax, for example, holds that feminism "requires simultaneously an incorporation, negation and transformation of all human history." "The Patriarchal Unconscious" in Discovering Reality, Sandra Harding and Merril Hintikka, eds. (Dordrecht: D. Reidel, 1983), 270.

Marsha H. Hanen, for example, alludes to "the extent to which a given account is conditioned by perspectives-historical and social context, class, gender, age, even individual psychology. Feminist at- tempts to break down or at least to question traditional ways of categorizing have been an important part of the movement. But the material and the structures have been extremely resistant." "Feminism, Objec- tivity, and Legal Truth," in Feminist Perspectives: Philosophical Essays on Method and Morals, Lorraine Code, Sheila Mullet, and Christine Overall, eds. (Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1988), 42.
